THE NEWS..LETTER
Baltimore, Md., February

VOL. XIV. No. H.

Thirty-fourth Anniversary of Founding of
Johns Hopkins Celebrated
Addreses Made by Drs. Falccner and Bright, and Interesting
Announcements from President Remsen. Degrees
Conferred and Prize Award Announced.
Fund On The Way.
Exercises commemorating the thirty-fourth anniversary were he'd in
McCoy Hall, Tuesay morning. A fanfare from "Lohengrin" (arranged by
Mr. Turnbull), was played by trumpets in the lobby at 10.45 a.m., as a
Signal for the academic procession to
Proceed to the Assembly Room.
The chief marshal was Professor
Matthews.
The president of the University,
the Mayor of the city, the Orator.
the Chaplain,Trustees,guests and Faculty, formed the first division, which
was under the direction of Professor
Brush, and made an imposing spectac!e with the van -colored gowns, betokening degrees from practically all
the great universities of the world.
The marshal of the second division,
the Alumni and candidates for Degrees, was Professor J. W. Williams,
president of the Alumni Association.
The graduate s'udents in Arts and
Sciences, the students of Medicine
'and undergradute students were marbhalled by Drs. Watson, Knox and
Abercrombie.
The music, which was under the
threction of Edwin Litchfield Turnbull (A.B., 1893), was furnished by
Players from the Peabody Conservatory
- and the United States Marine
Band of Washington.
The exercises were opened with
prayer. by Reverend Harris Eliot
Kirk, pastor of Franklin Street Presbyetrian Church.
In introducing the principal speaker of the day, President Remsen
Spoke of the very cordial feeling
and close intercourse between the two
universities, drawing attention to the
fact that there are ten Johns Hopkins men on the staff of the UniverSay of Toronto, and seven Toronto
vraduates among the members of our
Faculty.
, "During the last half-dozen years,"
Said President Remsen, "the University of Toronto has been undergoing
a reorganization, one of the most important steps of which was the calling of Dr. Robert A. Falconer to
the president's chair. I take pleasure

in introducing him as the orator of
the day."
President Falconer emphasized in
his address the conservatism of Canadian life. His address was an analysis of what seems to be the Canadian nationality, Two influences
were emphasized. First, the influx
of those in whom loyalty to the King
was the dominating factor, at the
time of the American Revolution..
"Those who remained," said Dr.
Falconer, "surpassed those who went
North, both in intellectual powers
and political ideals. I have no doubt
'hat your great leaders put forth
ideas which have not been surpassed. But the too,000 loyalists who
went North to settle in the provinces
and Ontario, although somewhat narrow in their beliefs, were a distinctly conservative element.
"In 1790 and the years following
'here was an immigrative element
which consisted of officers and soldiers of disbanded regiments. Sonic
came from the country districts of
England and these had conservative
views also, and, transported into a
world which was a wilderness, with
no means of communication with the
larger peoples of the South, lived
alone for over a generation and transmitted views unpolluted by outside
influences. These two elements,somewhat different but still practically the
same in the fundamental conservatism, which is one of the chief strata
in Canadian life, are all-important
factors.
"This reliability is evident at the
present time. We are brilliant, but
not fickle, emotional but steadfast,
'rue to the past and hopeful for the
future. We have always had a regard for law and order, even in the
outlying mining districts.
"The second element which differentiates us from the people across
the border is, that your ideals came
from the Continent, and the facility
with which you have assimilated the
innnigrant hordes which have poured
in upon you shows, perhaps, your
greater vitality.

22, 1910.

"We, on the other hand, have looked toward Great Britain. Annexation and revolut:onary sentiment have
been occasional, but no independent
agitation, and our eyes have looked
steadfastly toward England, and, unless you take into account out attitude toward our Mother Country,you
cannot understand the Canadian of
today. We have shared in the experiences of Great Britain. Pitt has
been ours, Peel, Beaconsfield, Salisbury, and we take a vital interest
in th budget struggle."
In mentioning the Canadian form
of government, Dr. Falconer made
a witty reference to the antagonistic
elements of the Republican party,represented by President Taft on the
one hand, and Speaker Cannon on
the other, saying that "we have no
governor in the sense that you have,
and no Speaker of the House who
may have a different policy."
"In education our union with England is marked, in ecclesiastical affpirs we have followed the leadership of the Old World."
"Last summer theer were two important celebrations at Geneva," said
President Remsen, "one was of a
university nature, the other in honor
of Calvin. I have asked Professor
Bright, who represented this University at the convention, to tell us
something, about them."
Professor Bright, after speaking of
the meaning of the Genevan celebration, and reviewing in detail the work
and services of Calvin, mentioned
the analogy to Johns Hopkins.
"Calvin began his school very much
in the manner that has become known
to us here through the 'launching of
a university.' This coincidence is
nothing more, but also nothing less,
that proof that there is but one true
method for the founding of a university. Secure three or four or more
geat scholars as teahcers, and the
thing is done. Calvin began (as did
President Gilman) with the professorship of Greek. Theodore Beza,
then at the school in Lausanne, was
designated professor of Greek in the
college that was to he opened the
next year.
"In the lineal inheritance of Calvinistic influences in America, Puritan New England was, of course, a
preferred heir. But there was a collateral bestowal by the University of
Geneva upon Virginia that deserves
to be kept in perpetual memembrance.
This was involved in a novel incident in the history of American univerFities, made familiar to the wider
public through one of the published
Continued on page 4, column 2.

THE PRESIDENT'S
ANNOIJ NCEMENTS
—o—
Homewood and Academic Expansion—Two Millions Needed.
In taking up that part of the program which probably was of greatest
interest to the audience — the Announcements of the President of the
University—President Remsen spoke
briefly as follows:
"Announcements," he said in introduction, "is not at all a good title
for the remarks it is my duty to
make. 'Statements' is perhaps a better word; but it seems to me that
medley is still more inclusive.
"The reception of messages from
newly formed alumni associations in
other universities is extremely gratifying, testifying the increasing active interest of Hopkins men in the
University. Among the first letters
to arrive were two from the alumni
of the University of West Virginia
and North Carolina."
The result of the recent election
for members of the Alumni Council
was as follows: Dr. Thomas S. Baker, Dr. Thomas R. Brown, B. Howeil
Griswold, Jr., and Dr. St. George
Sioussat.
Degrees conferred at this time
were:
Doctors of Philosophy-Frederic Harvey Blodgett, Washington, D. C., S.B. Rutgers College,
1897, and M.S., 1899, in the Departments of Botany, Biology and Geology.
Preston Hampton Edwards, Darlington, S. C., A.B. and A.M., University of Virginia, 19oo, in the departments of Physics, Applied Electricity, and Mathematics.
The lecturer on the Turnbull
Foundation for I9I will be Dr. Maurice Francis Eagan, Professor of
History in Catholic University of
America, and United States Minister
to Denmark. He will give a series
of eight lectures in March.
The Herter Lectureship in Medical
Science will be given in 1910 by the
Professor of Pathology in the University of Strassburg, Vienna. In
1911 it will be given by Professor
Albert Kursal.
The Henrico Medallion for 1910
was presented to Henry M. Wagstaff. This prize is the gift (made
in 1902) of the Colonial Dames of
America, Chapter r, and consists of
a copper medallion, bas-relief, commemorating the foundation of a university at Henrico, in Virvinia, in

invest7gatiens of our late Professor
Herbert B. Adams. I refer to the
ac of Thomas Jefferson in seriously
proposing `to translate the Academy
of Geneva in a body to this country;'
to transplant the institution, root and
branch, from its native soil to that
of Virginia. 'While upon foreign
iFs'ons in the interest of the United
States,' writes Professor Adams,'Jefferson kept making inquiries into
the best systems of university education in the Old World.' After expressing various judgments he finally
wrote, in the year 1791, as follows:
'With respect to the schools of Europe my mind is perfectly made up.
and on full inquiry. The best in the
On the
world is Edinburgh. . .
continent of Europe, no place is comparable to Geneva.' After his return
to America, it is reported that he
was wont to speak of these universities as 'the two eyes of Europe.' Before that return, however, the academic repose of the University of Geneva became disturbed by reason of
having fallen into disfavor with the
revolutionary party, and this circumqance led Jefferson somewhat precipitously to indulge the belief that
he could, without detriment to either
transplant cne of the eyes of
Furope into an American socket. But
Wasihngton, to whom the plan was
at once submitted, disapproved of
such drastic surgery, and his arguments prevailed. The new country
was not yet prepared for a national
university, this was the implication.
and in no conceivable circumstances
nrYsablv, could such a mechanical
transference ever be advantageous.
"This extraord.nary incident conrec's the nan-es of crtivin. Washington, and .Terferson, three oc
e-,:nent advocates of the University
as an indisnensable factor in the
economy of the Commonwealth. Jefferson surveyed his life and concluded with the wish that future generaCons might know him for the accomnlishemnt of three acts of public
cerv:ce : the composition of the Decnf Independence. the corwepr:n., of tbe statute of Virginia for
,
reliffiotts freedom, and the foundin;'
nf the University of Virginia. Wash:n-ton served as chancellor of the
renege of William and Mary from
ti—e nreceding his presidency of
5 Trifeti States to the end of his
1;fe; and he was the father of the
idea of a nat'onal university. When

Calvin contemplated future observances of a commemorative character
he esteemed only on day in the year
worthy to be distinguished by an annual jubilee; it was the F,th day oF
June, the birthday of the University
cf Geneva.
The observance of Founder's Day
at the Johns Hopkins University has
purposely been made coincident with
the commemoration of the father of
the idea of a national university ill
America. This idea, however, links
Washing-ten with Jefferson, and both
with Calvin, thus establishing a clear
title to a very true and not too remote relation between our exercises
today and the elaborate historic observances at Geneva last summer. In
other words, is it not deeply true that
our Founder's Day must always be
specifically commemorative of these
three men, high-priests in the service
of human progress? And if we hearken to the teaching of their lives, interpreting the culminating aim of
their most devoted efforts, we shall
be freshly admonished, from year to
year, that a commonwealth derives
its highest power and surest distinction from its university."

THE NEWS..LETTER
Baltimore, Md., February

VOL. XIV. No. H.

Thirty-fourth Anniversary of Founding of
Johns Hopkins Celebrated
Addreses Made by Drs. Falccner and Bright, and Interesting
Announcements from President Remsen. Degrees
Conferred and Prize Award Announced.
Fund On The Way.
Exercises commemorating the thirty-fourth anniversary were he'd in
McCoy Hall, Tuesay morning. A fanfare from "Lohengrin" (arranged by
Mr. Turnbull), was played by trumpets in the lobby at 10.45 a.m., as a
Signal for the academic procession to
Proceed to the Assembly Room.
The chief marshal was Professor
Matthews.
The president of the University,
the Mayor of the city, the Orator.
the Chaplain,Trustees,guests and Faculty, formed the first division, which
was under the direction of Professor
Brush, and made an imposing spectac!e with the van -colored gowns, betokening degrees from practically all
the great universities of the world.
The marshal of the second division,
the Alumni and candidates for Degrees, was Professor J. W. Williams,
president of the Alumni Association.
The graduate s'udents in Arts and
Sciences, the students of Medicine
'and undergradute students were marbhalled by Drs. Watson, Knox and
Abercrombie.
The music, which was under the
threction of Edwin Litchfield Turnbull (A.B., 1893), was furnished by
Players from the Peabody Conservatory
- and the United States Marine
Band of Washington.
The exercises were opened with
prayer. by Reverend Harris Eliot
Kirk, pastor of Franklin Street Presbyetrian Church.
In introducing the principal speaker of the day, President Remsen
Spoke of the very cordial feeling
and close intercourse between the two
universities, drawing attention to the
fact that there are ten Johns Hopkins men on the staff of the UniverSay of Toronto, and seven Toronto
vraduates among the members of our
Faculty.
, "During the last half-dozen years,"
Said President Remsen, "the University of Toronto has been undergoing
a reorganization, one of the most important steps of which was the calling of Dr. Robert A. Falconer to
the president's chair. I take pleasure

in introducing him as the orator of
the day."
President Falconer emphasized in
his address the conservatism of Canadian life. His address was an analysis of what seems to be the Canadian nationality, Two influences
were emphasized. First, the influx
of those in whom loyalty to the King
was the dominating factor, at the
time of the American Revolution..
"Those who remained," said Dr.
Falconer, "surpassed those who went
North, both in intellectual powers
and political ideals. I have no doubt
'hat your great leaders put forth
ideas which have not been surpassed. But the too,000 loyalists who
went North to settle in the provinces
and Ontario, although somewhat narrow in their beliefs, were a distinctly conservative element.
"In 1790 and the years following
'here was an immigrative element
which consisted of officers and soldiers of disbanded regiments. Sonic
came from the country districts of
England and these had conservative
views also, and, transported into a
world which was a wilderness, with
no means of communication with the
larger peoples of the South, lived
alone for over a generation and transmitted views unpolluted by outside
influences. These two elements,somewhat different but still practically the
same in the fundamental conservatism, which is one of the chief strata
in Canadian life, are all-important
factors.
"This reliability is evident at the
present time. We are brilliant, but
not fickle, emotional but steadfast,
'rue to the past and hopeful for the
future. We have always had a regard for law and order, even in the
outlying mining districts.
"The second element which differentiates us from the people across
the border is, that your ideals came
from the Continent, and the facility
with which you have assimilated the
innnigrant hordes which have poured
in upon you shows, perhaps, your
greater vitality.

22, 1910.

"We, on the other hand, have looked toward Great Britain. Annexation and revolut:onary sentiment have
been occasional, but no independent
agitation, and our eyes have looked
steadfastly toward England, and, unless you take into account out attitude toward our Mother Country,you
cannot understand the Canadian of
today. We have shared in the experiences of Great Britain. Pitt has
been ours, Peel, Beaconsfield, Salisbury, and we take a vital interest
in th budget struggle."
In mentioning the Canadian form
of government, Dr. Falconer made
a witty reference to the antagonistic
elements of the Republican party,represented by President Taft on the
one hand, and Speaker Cannon on
the other, saying that "we have no
governor in the sense that you have,
and no Speaker of the House who
may have a different policy."
"In education our union with England is marked, in ecclesiastical affpirs we have followed the leadership of the Old World."
"Last summer theer were two important celebrations at Geneva," said
President Remsen, "one was of a
university nature, the other in honor
of Calvin. I have asked Professor
Bright, who represented this University at the convention, to tell us
something, about them."
Professor Bright, after speaking of
the meaning of the Genevan celebration, and reviewing in detail the work
and services of Calvin, mentioned
the analogy to Johns Hopkins.
"Calvin began his school very much
in the manner that has become known
to us here through the 'launching of
a university.' This coincidence is
nothing more, but also nothing less,
that proof that there is but one true
method for the founding of a university. Secure three or four or more
geat scholars as teahcers, and the
thing is done. Calvin began (as did
President Gilman) with the professorship of Greek. Theodore Beza,
then at the school in Lausanne, was
designated professor of Greek in the
college that was to he opened the
next year.
"In the lineal inheritance of Calvinistic influences in America, Puritan New England was, of course, a
preferred heir. But there was a collateral bestowal by the University of
Geneva upon Virginia that deserves
to be kept in perpetual memembrance.
This was involved in a novel incident in the history of American univerFities, made familiar to the wider
public through one of the published
Continued on page 4, column 2.

Price, 3 cents per copy.
THE PRESIDENT'S
ANNOIJ NCEMENTS
—o—
Homewood and Academic Expansion—Two Millions Needed.
In taking up that part of the program which probably was of greatest
interest to the audience — the Announcements of the President of the
University—President Remsen spoke
briefly as follows:
"Announcements," he said in introduction, "is not at all a good title
for the remarks it is my duty to
make. 'Statements' is perhaps a better word; but it seems to me that
medley is still more inclusive.
"The reception of messages from
newly formed alumni associations in
other universities is extremely gratifying, testifying the increasing active interest of Hopkins men in the
University. Among the first letters
to arrive were two from the alumni
of the University of West Virginia
and North Carolina."
The result of the recent election
for members of the Alumni Council
was as follows: Dr. Thomas S. Baker, Dr. Thomas R. Brown, B. Howeil
Griswold, Jr., and Dr. St. George
Sioussat.
Degrees conferred at this time
were:
Doctors of Philosophy-Frederic Harvey Blodgett, Washington, D. C., S.B. Rutgers College,
1897, and M.S., 1899, in the Departments of Botany, Biology and Geology.
Preston Hampton Edwards, Darlington, S. C., A.B. and A.M., University of Virginia, 19oo, in the departments of Physics, Applied Electricity, and Mathematics.
The lecturer on the Turnbull
Foundation for I9I will be Dr. Maurice Francis Eagan, Professor of
History in Catholic University of
America, and United States Minister
to Denmark. He will give a series
of eight lectures in March.
The Herter Lectureship in Medical
Science will be given in 1910 by the
Professor of Pathology in the University of Strassburg, Vienna. In
1911 it will be given by Professor
Albert Kursal.
The Henrico Medallion for 1910
was presented to Henry M. Wagstaff. This prize is the gift (made
in 1902) of the Colonial Dames of
America, Chapter r, and consists of
a copper medallion, bas-relief, commemorating the foundation of a university at Henrico, in Virvinia, in

ac of Thomas Jefferson in seriously
proposing `to translate the Academy

of Virginia. 'While upon foreign
iFs'ons in the interest of the United
States,' writes Professor Adams,'Jefferson kept making inquiries into
the best systems of university education in the Old World.' After expressing various judgments he finally
wrote, in the year 1791, as follows:
'With respect to the schools of Europe my mind is perfectly made up.
and on full inquiry. The best in the
On the
world is Edinburgh. . .
continent of Europe, no place is comparable to Geneva.' After his return
to America, it is reported that he
was wont to speak of these universities as 'the two eyes of Europe.' Before that return, however, the academic repose of the University of Geneva became disturbed by reason of
having fallen into disfavor with the
revolutionary party, and this circumqance led Jefferson somewhat precipitously to indulge the belief that
he could, without detriment to either
transplant cne of the eyes of
Furope into an American socket. But
Wasihngton, to whom the plan was
at once submitted, disapproved of
such drastic surgery, and his arguments prevailed. The new country
was not yet prepared for a national
university, this was the implication.
and in no conceivable circumstances
nrYsablv, could such a mechanical
transference ever be advantageous.

nf the University of Virginia. Wash:n-ton served as chancellor of the

worthy to be distinguished by an annual jubilee; it was the F,th day oF
June, the birthday of the University
cf Geneva.
The observance of Founder's Day
at the Johns Hopkins University has
purposely been made coincident with
the commemoration of the father of
the idea of a national university ill
America. This idea, however, links
Washing-ten with Jefferson, and both
with Calvin, thus establishing a clear
title to a very true and not too remote relation between our exercises
today and the elaborate historic observances at Geneva last summer. In
other words, is it not deeply true that
our Founder's Day must always be
specifically commemorative of these
three men, high-priests in the service
of human progress? And if we hearken to the teaching of their lives, interpreting the culminating aim of
their most devoted efforts, we shall
be freshly admonished, from year to
year, that a commonwealth derives
its highest power and surest distinction from its university."
